Fax: +39 095 580138. Graphical abstract Photocatalytic and catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol, representative of volatile organic compounds (VOC’s), were compared over mixed TiO2–CeO2-based catalysts. The effect of different amounts of CeO2 and the presence of gold (1wt%) on TiO2 was investigated. In the photocatalytic oxidation CeO2 had a negative effect on the performance towards the alcohol conversion of both TiO2–CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts, being Au/TiO2 the most active system. On the contrary mixed TiO2–CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2 samples showed a higher catalytic oxidation efficiency for 2-propanol conversion compared to the single oxides. In this case Au/CeO2 catalyst had the best performance. On the basis of characterization data (XRD, Raman spectroscopy, EDX, BET Surface area determinations, H2-TPR, DRIFT and DRS), it was proposed that the interaction of gold with TiO2 caused an enhancement of the partial photo-oxidation activity to acetone due to an increase of the charge separation between the excited electron and the hole of TiO2, whereas the coexistence of gold and both TiO2 and CeO2 oxides favoured the total oxidation of the alcohol to CO2. The catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol is, instead, mainly directed by the presence of a reducible oxide support as CeO2, necessary to enable a strong interaction with gold nanoparticles, providing very active lattice oxygen atoms. Keywords Selective oxidation Catalytic combustion Photocatalysis Titanium dioxide Cerium oxide Gold 1 Introduction Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC’s) are considered highly dangerous pollutants due to both their intrinsic toxicity and indirect production of highly toxic ozone via photochemical reactions. The term VOC’s encompasses many compounds including non-methane hydrocarbons, alcohols, aldehydes and organic acids. Exposure to VOC’s may trigger many serious health problems, such as eye, nose, skin, and throat irritation, coughing, headaches, and cancer, even at very low concentrations [1,2]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to abate efficiently and cost-effectively these compounds. Many practical methods, such as adsorption, thermal combustion, catalytic oxidation and biofiltration have been adopted to remove VOC’s [3–6]. Up to now the catalytic oxidation is one of the most efficient and relatively inexpensive route to reduce VOC’s at low concentrations. Two classes of catalysts, noble metals and transition metal oxides, are the most promising ones in the area of VOC’s combustion [7,8]. Regarding unsupported metal oxide catalysts, CeO2 alone or combined with other elements in mixed or doped oxides (CoOx, MnOx, CuO, ZnO, Fe2O3, TiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2) is recognized as an efficient catalyst for the total oxidation of several types of VOC molecules [9–11]. It is known that CeO2 increases the dispersion of active components because it acts as an oxygen reservoir which stores and releases oxygen via the redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+ under oxidizing and reducing conditions [12,13]. The VOC’s oxidation performance of CeO2 can be strongly improved by the presence of gold. Au/CeO2 is, in fact, among the most active systems for the oxidation of oxygenated VOC’s (alcohols, aldehydes, ketones and esters) [14] and its performance is dependent on many factors, namely the nature and the properties of the support, loading, size, shape and electronic state of gold nanoparticles, preparation method and pre-treatment conditions of catalysts, nature and concentration of the organic molecule to be combusted [14,15]. The high activity of Au/CeO2 was ascribed to the high surface oxygen mobility of the gold/CeO2 system, the lattice oxygen of the oxide being involved in the reaction pathway through a Mars–Van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [16,17]. In this contest small gold nanoparticles have been reported to enhance the reactivity of CeO2 lattice oxygen by weakening the surface CeO bonds adjacent to Au atom [18]. Photocatalysis is one of the most attractive advanced oxidation technologies for decomposition of organic pollutants in water or air [19]. Several photocatalysts have been developed [20], TiO2 being the most studied and also the most likely to be brought to an industrial scale, due to its non-toxicity, abundance and photo/chemical stability [19]. It is well established that the photocatalytic oxidation process is initiated through the photogeneration of electron/hole pairs under light radiation. Owing to its powerful oxidation capability the photohole is able to mineralize almost all types of organic compounds. However, the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 nanomaterials is still not up to the mark to meet out the practical needs under direct sunlight irradiation because of two main drawbacks: (a) the large intrinsic band gap of TiO2 (ca. 3.2 or 3.0eV for anatase and rutile phases, respectively) severely restricts its utilization under visible light; (b) the fast electron-hole recombination often results in a low quantum yield and poor photocatalytic activity [21,22]. One of the promising strategies to enhance the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 is loading of noble metals on its surface [23–25]. Various metals such as Au [26], Ag [24,27], Pt [28] or others have been successfully applied. The enhanced photocatalytic activity of metal/TiO2 is caused by the space-charge separation of photo-excited electron-hole pairs by the loaded metals [29,30]. Fermi level of noble metals such as Au nanoparticle (NP) is located at more positive potential than the energy level of TiO2 conduction band (CB). Thus the photo-excited electrons in the TiO2-CB can be transferred to the metal NP, suppressing the charge recombination taking place in TiO2. The holes in TiO2-VB will then have longer lifetime, which is obviously advantageous for oxidation reactions [31]. Another approach to enhance the TiO2 photocatalytic efficiency is the combination of TiO2 with other metal oxides such as SnO2, ZnO, Bi2O3, which have been also reported to provide higher photocatalytic degradation rates of harmful organic chemicals [32–36]. Among TiO2-based mixed oxides the nanocomposites of TiO2 with CeO2 have received a great deal of interest because of special f and d electron orbital structures and the unique UV absorbing ability, high thermal stability, high electrical conductivity and large oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 which can improve significantly the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 [37,38]. To date there are only few studies in literature that analyze the analogies and the differences in the catalyst performance and the reaction mechanism in photocatalytic and catalytic oxidation of organic compounds. Ozen et al., studied the CO oxidation on Pt/TiO2 catalyst under dark and illuminated conditions. They observed that the rate enhancement due to the presence of Pt was merely due to thermal reactions with no contribution from UV illumination under the sensitivity conditions of the experiments [39]. Avila et al., examined the gas-phase photo-assisted mineralization of volatile organic compounds (toluene and trichloroethylene, as VOC’s model) by monolithic Pt-TiO2 catalysts, and they found that the complete mineralization of VOC’s by photocatalytic oxidation is strongly dependent on the type of compound to be removed [40]. In this work we aim to evaluate the performance of TiO2-based catalysts for both photocatalytic and catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol, as a VOC model. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mixed TiO2 (Degussa P25)-CeO2 composites with different weight percentages of CeO2 (1, 5, 10, 15) were prepared. Different aliquots of TiO2 were impregnated with a proper amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solution, and the slurries were stirred for 4h, dried at 120°C and finally calcined in air at 350°C for 4h. Calcination at 350°C for 4h was also carried out on the bare TiO2. CeO2 used in this work was prepared according to ref [18] by precipitation with KOH (0.1M) from water solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, and subsequent filtration and calcination in air at 450°C for 4h of the obtained solid. Gold (1wt%) was deposited on the bare or mixed TiO2–CeO2 oxides by deposition–precipitation. After the pH of the aqueous solutions of the gold precursor (HAuCl4) was adjusted to the value of 8 by using an aqueous solution of KOH (0.1M), the support was added under vigorous stirring (500rpm), keeping the slurry at 70°C for 3h. The obtained slurry was kept digesting for 24h, filtered and washed several times (until disappearance of chlorides), dried at 110°C and finally ground before use. The samples were coded as TiCeXX% and Au/TiCeXX%, where XX indicates the wt% of CeO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was carried out in a conventional flow apparatus with a TCD detector at heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 using 5vol% H2 in Ar. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out with a Bruker AXSD5005 X-ray diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation. Diffraction peaks of crystalline phases were compared with those of standard compounds present in the JCPDS Data File. EDX analysis was performed using an INCA Energy Oxford solid state detector. Morphologies were examined through field emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) using a ZEISS SUPRA 55 VP microscope. Surface area measurements were performed by using the BET nitrogen adsorption method with a Sorptomatic series 1990 (Thermo Quest). Before tests all samples were outgassed (10−3 Torr) at 120°C. Raman spectra were carried out exciting with an Ar ion laser (514.5nm) and analyzing with a Jobin Yvon 450mm focal length monochromator, equipped with a CCD camera detector, cooled at 77K. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000–600cm−1 with a PerkinElmer FT-IR System 2000, KBr being employed to obtain the background spectrum. Visible-ultraviolet reflectance spectra were obtained by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy by using a Shimadzu UV-2401 PC instrument. BaSO4 was the reference sample and the spectra were recorded in the range 200–800nm. 2.3 Photocatalytic activity experiments The photocatalytic oxidation tests were carried out by using a cylindrical continuous Pyrex photoreactor, operating in gas-solid regime. A porous glass septum in the inlet of the flow allowed to distribute homogeneously the gaseous mixture. The reactivity runs were carried out with 300mg of solid powder by simply dispersing it as a thin layer inside the photoreactor (the fixed bed height was ca. 0.3mm). The gas feeding the photoreactor consisted of 2-propanol (0.1mM) and air, the first one fed by means of a B. Braun Perfusor VI infusion pump, the second one by a mass gas-flow controller. The flow rate of the gaseous stream for the photo-assisted runs was 20cm3 min−1. All runs were carried out at atmospheric pressure. The reactor and the pipes of the set-up to and from the reactor were heated by an electric resistance and K-type thermocouples allowed to monitor the temperature in the whole system. The reactions were carried out at 25°C and 50°C and the temperature inside the photoreactor was maintained constant by means of a refrigeration water jacket surrounding the lamp and filtering the infrared radiations. The set-up was illuminated from the top with a Helios-Italquartz 125W medium pressure Hg lamp and the irradiance reaching the photoreactor, measured in the range 300–400nm with a UVX Digital radiometer, was equal to 1.5mWcm−2. The runs lasted 80min and samples of the reacting fluid were analyzed by a Shimadzu GC 2010 equipped with a Phenomenex Zebron Wax-Plus (30μm×0.32μm×0.53μm) column and a FID detector using He as carrier gas. CO2 determination was performed by a HP 6890 Series GC System equipped with a packed GC 60/80Carboxen™-1000 column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol was carried out in the gas phase at atmospheric pressure in a continuous-flow reactor filled with the catalyst (50mg, 80–140mesh) diluted with inert glass powder. For each experiment the reactor temperature was ramped at the rate of 10°Cmin−1 up to the chosen temperature. Then the reactant mixture was passed over the catalyst for 15min (to reach a steady-state) before sampling the products for analysis. By using the above procedure, conversion and selectivities were reproducible within 3–5%. Preliminary runs, carried out at different flow-rates, showed the absence of external diffusional limitations. The absence of internal diffusion limitations was verified by running experiments with different grain size powders. We excluded the occurrence of heat transfer limitations, because we found that the temperature of the reactor at different heights was substantially the same, reasonably due to the low concentration of the reactants used in the catalytic tests. The reactant mixture (0.1vol.% 2-propanol, 10vol.% air, balance in helium) was fed to the reactor by flowing a part of the He stream through a saturator containing the VOC and then mixing with air and He before reaching the catalyst. A flow rate of the reactant mixture of 20cm3 min−1 with a resulting space velocity (GHSV) of 7.6×10−3 molVOC h−1 g cat −1 was used. The effluent gases were analysed on-line by a gas chromatograph, equipped with a packed column with 10% FFAP on Chromosorb W and FID detector, and by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (VG quadropoles). The carbon balance was always higher than 95%. 3 Results 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 Structural and textural properties of supported gold catalysts XRD patterns of TiO2, Au/TiO2, TiCe10% and Au/TiCe10% samples (Fig. 1 ) showed that anatase was the main phase with a minor amount of rutile phase present. Interestingly the peaks associated to cubic CeO2 were observed only for the Au/TiCe10% system, whereas on the corresponding sample without gold (TiCe10%) these peaks had a much lower intensity, thus indicating that the introduction of gold probably favours the crystallization of CeO2. The absence of a signal for gold both in Au/TiO2 and Au/TiCe10% suggests that on these samples the particles size of gold was below the detection limit (around 3–4nm) of the instrument under the experimental conditions used. The formation of small gold particles by deposition-precipitation has been widely reported in the literature [14,16]. The average crystallites size of the investigated oxides was determined by applying the Scherrer formula using the (101) anatase diffraction peak (2θ =25°). The presence of CeO2 and/or Au induced a decrease in the anatase crystallites size which is ca. 24nm for the bare TiO2, 22nm for the TiCe10% sample, 21nm for Au/TiO2 and 19nm for the Au/TiCe10%. As reported in the literature the presence of CeO2 inhibits the crystallite growth of the anatase phase, retarding the transition from amorphous titania to anatase [41,42]. The Raman spectra of TiO2, CeO2, Au/TiO2, TiCe10% and Au/TiCe10% samples are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The signals at 403, 524 and 647cm−1 are characteristic of the anatase phase and that at 450cm−1 of the rutile phase [43,44]. The CeO2 fluorite type phase was detected only in the Au/TiCe10% sample, as confirmed by the band at 468cm−1 corresponding to the CeO2 cubic phase [45] which is well visible in the spectra of pure CeO2. According to XRD results, the above data suggest that the presence both of TiO2 and gold in the Au/TiCe10% sample favours the crystallization of CeO2. EDX analysis of TiCe10% and Au/TiCe10% samples was carried out in order to highlight differences in the surface composition of these mixed oxides. The elemental composition of these catalysts is reported in Table 1 . For the Au/TiCe10% sample the atomic surface percentage of Ce is about 4 times higher than that of TiCe10% (5.07 and 1.21 respectively), pointing out that the presence of gold on mixed oxides leads to a considerable cerium surface enrichment. Textural properties (surface area and mean pore diameter) were evaluated by N 2 adsorption–desorption measurements and the results are reported in Table 2 . According to the literature [18,46] the precipitation method, used for the synthesis of CeO2, allowed to obtain a sample with high surface area (111.2m2 g−1) and small pores (about 3nm). TiO2 exhibited a surface area of 44.7m2 g−1, lower than the values reported in literature for the Degussa P25 (50–54m2 g−1), reasonably due to pre-treatment conditions of TiO2 (calcination at 350°C) [47,48]. In the TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxides the presence of CeO2 induced only a very slight increase of surface area (2–6m2 g−1) compared to the bare TiO2 with a consequent slight decrease of the average pores diameter. The presence of gold did not change significantly the textural properties of investigated bare or mixed oxides. UV–vis reflectance spectra (Fig. 3 ) were recorded to determine the band-gap energy values of the samples. TiO2 is an indirect semiconductor [49] so that the band gap energy, E g, of the samples can be determined by plotting the modified Kubelka–Munk function, [F(R ∞′) hν]1/2, versus the energy of the exciting light [50]. The results were reported in Table 2. The lower values of E g of TiO2–CeO2 samples (2.93eV) compared to bare TiO2 (2.98eV) were related to the presence of CeO2. For the cerium-based nanomaterials, in fact, a bathochromic shift towards the visible region compared to bare TiO2 was observed (Fig. 3A), and the CeO2 sample had the lowest value of E g (2.90eV). Some authors correlated the lowering E g value of CeO2–TiO2 nanocomposites to the substitution of Ti4+ cations by Ce4+ cations in TiO2 network [51,52]. In the case of gold based samples (Fig. 3B), no substantial variation of E g values was noticed with respect to bare TiO2. All of the gold catalysts presented a wide absorbance band in the visible range, at around 550nm. This band is usually assigned to the plasmon resonance of gold nanoparticles [53]. DRIFT spectra, carried out on investigated catalysts, are displayed in Fig. 4 A. For all of the samples it is possible to notice a broad band at about 3380–3400cm−1, associated with the stretching vibration of water molecules, as confirmed by the small peak at 1600cm−1, due to the bending vibration of the OH group. It must be underlined that in TiO2 based samples the presence of TiOH groups also contribute to this latter peak. The broad and very strong band at 1000–800cm−1, visible for all the TiO2 containing samples, can be attributed to TiOTi vibrations of TiO2 [54,55]. For the CeO2-based catalyst (CeO2, TiCe10%, Au/TiCe10% and Au/CeO2) the broad envelope of bands below 1800cm−1 suggests the presence of carbonate species [56] generally observed for CeO2-based materials due to the interaction of surface CeO2 oxygens with atmospheric carbon dioxide [57]. In our case the position of the bands indicates the formation of monodentate carbonate species (ν asCOO− 1560–1470cm−1, ν sCOO− 1370–1300cm−1) [58,59]. Interestingly in this zone (Fig. 4B) substantial differences among various samples can be observed. In all samples the two signals attributed to monodentate species appear shifted compared to bare CeO2. The value of the splitting (Δν=νasCOO− − νsCOO−) is often used to evaluate the basicity of the oxygens participating in the carbonate formation as it gradually increases with the covalent character of the MO bond (decreasing oxygen basicity) [59]. In this case Au/CeO2 presents a Δν value of 211.7cm−1, whereas the bare CeO2 of 132.2cm−1, pointing out that the presence of gold decreases the oxygen basicity. In the TiCe10% and Au/TiCe10% systems the νasCOO− band is not well resolved overlapping with the νOH band. However it can be noticed that the ν sCOO− band is shifted to lower wave numbers (1352.2 and 1327.5cm−1 respectively for TiCe10% and Au/TiCe10%) compared to the bare CeO2 (1357cm−1). This shift, far more evident for the Au/TiCe10% sample, points out that the co-presence of TiO2 and Au decreases strongly the basicity of CeO2 oxygens. 3.1.2 Reduction properties of supported gold catalysts: H2-TPR measurements Fig. 5 reports the H2-TPR profiles of investigated catalysts in the 30–550°C temperature range. As reported in the literature, the profile obtained for TiO2 does not show H2 consumption and reduction peaks, the reduction of TiO2 P25 occurring, in fact, at temperature higher than 600°C [60]. Also for the Au/TiO2 sample no reduction peaks were observed, indicating the presence of reduced Au [61,62]. The bare CeO2 presents a broad reduction peak starting at about 350°C and centred at around 500°C, attributed to the reduction of surface capping oxygen of the oxide [63,64]. On mixed TiCe10% sample a reduction feature in the same temperature range of CeO2 can be seen. The reduction is sensibly lower in intensity than on bare CeO2 sample, in agreement with the lower content of CeO2 in the mixed oxide. The profile of Au/CeO2 showed a single peak at 145°C. This peak can be attributed to the reduction of CeO2 surface oxygen species, which occurs at much lower temperature. This shift reflects the ability of highly dispersed gold to weaken the CeO bond, thus increasing the mobility of the lattice oxygens [65]. Notably the occurrence of spillover phenomena have been reported over gold/ceria and gold/ceria-mixed oxides [66,67]. This could justify the higher H2 consumption observed on Au/TiCe10% and Au/CeO2 sample compared to the bare CeO2. Similarly, the Au/TiCe10% sample showed a single peak at 185°C. The appearance of this peak at higher temperature compared with that of Au/CeO2 can be reasonably related to the lower gold-ceria interaction as a consequence of the lower content of ceria on the Au/TiCe10% sample. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Photocatalytic oxidation of 2-propanol: TiO2-CeO2 and Au/TiO2-CeO2 catalysts Photocatalytic oxidation data of 2-propanol (time on stream: 80min) in term of alcohol conversion and selectivity to acetone and CO2 at 25°C are depicted in Fig. 6 A. As far as 2-propanol conversion is concerned, the best results were obtained by using the Au/TiO2 catalyst (96%), followed by TiO2 (70%), TiCe1% (68%) and Au/TiCe10% samples (64%). As reported in the Introduction section the enhancement of photocatalytic activity of TiO2, due to the presence of gold particles, is attributed to the different Fermi levels of the two species resulting in an increase of the charge separation between the excited electron (e−) and hole (h+) [31,68,69]. The high activity of Degussa P25 could be due to the existence of an interaction between the two phases of TiO2 (80% anatase, 20% rutile), that enhances the electron-hole separation and increases the total photoeffiency [70–73]. The bare CeO2 showed a low activity for the conversion of 2-propanol (31%), while on the TiO2–CeO2 system the values of alcohol conversion decreased by increasing the wt% of CeO2, being 68% (similar to bare TiO2) for TiCe1%, 56% for TiCe5%, 45% for TiCe10% and 27% for TiCe15% samples. As regards the selectivity to acetone, the TiO2 P25 had the highest value (97%) in agreement with the data reported in the literature for this reaction [74,75]. Also in this case the increase of the amount of CeO2 had a negative effect which caused a decrease of selectivity down to 92%, 74%, 48% and 46% for TiCe1%, TiCe5%, TiCe10% and TiCe15% systems, respectively. The Au/TiO2 sample was more selective to acetone (64%) compared to the Au/TiCe10% catalyst (37%). The selectivity to CO2 had an opposite trend. The Au/TiCe10% system showed the highest selectivity (60%) while for the TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxides it increased with the wt% of CeO2, being higher for the TiCe10% and TiCe15% samples (49% and 51% respectively). By considering that the bare CeO2 showed a considerable value of CO2 selectivity (33%), these results suggest that the presence of CeO2 greater affects the total oxidation of 2-propanol to CO2 rather than the partial oxidation to acetone. In all of the photocatalytic tests with the TiO2-based samples, the formation of propene was detected, with very low selectivity (1–3%). As reported in the literature [76,77] the selective oxidation of 2-propanol can proceed with two reaction routes: the dehydration to propene and water or the oxidative dehydrogenation to acetone and water. In this case the formation of propene (not detected for Au/CeO2 and CeO2 catalysts) is due to the more acidic nature of TiO2 with respect to CeO2 [78–80]. The photoactivity at 50°C is reported in Fig. 6B. Concerning the 2-propanol conversion, the increase of temperature caused a slight enhancement of alcohol conversion values. Similarly to the results obtained at 25°C the best activity was displayed by Au/TiO2 (98%), followed by TiO2 (76%), TiCe1% (73%) and Au/TiCe10% (68%). The TiCe10% and TiCe15% samples, notwithstanding a greater enhancement of the values of 2-propanol conversion with temperature (10% and 20%), still remain the least active. Moreover it is possible to notice an increase of CO2 selectivity for all of the TiO2–CeO2 samples, the Au/TiCe10% sample being also in this case the most selective catalyst. 3.2.2 Catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol: TiO2–CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts Fig. 7 showed the catalytic activity data on TiO2–CeO2 based catalysts. In particular for the conversion of 2-propanol (Fig. 7A) it is possible to note that the mixed composites had a much higher activity compared to bare TiO2 and CeO2, as focused also in Table 3 where T 10, T 50, and T 90 conversion values (i.e. the temperature at which 10%, 50% and 90% conversion were reached) are reported. Interestingly, already at very low amount of CeO2 (TiCe1% sample) the conversion of 2-propanol was shifted to much lower temperatures. By increasing the amount of CeO2 the conversion slightly increased up to 10wt% CeO2 (TiCe10%), then remaining almost constant for higher percentage (TiCe15%). The TiO2–CeO2 samples (Fig. 7B and Table 3) with higher amount of CeO2 (5–15wt%) showed higher yields to acetone at lower temperatures (95–97% at ca. 230°C), compared to other samples, namely TiCe1% (65% at 230°C), TiO2 (87% at 305°C) or CeO2 (35% at 335°C). In terms of conversion to CO2 (Fig. 7C) it can be noted that all TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxide samples exhibited higher values compared to bare oxides, TiO2 being the least active sample towards the total oxidation. Similar to the photocatalytic reaction, also in this case only for the TiO2-based catalysts a small percentage of propene was detected at temperature above 330°C. The effect of gold addition was studied on TiO2, CeO2 and TiO2-10%CeO2 oxides (Fig. 8 ). Data reported in Fig. 8 and Table 3 show that the Au/CeO2 sample is the most active one, exhibiting the lowest light-off temperature (84°C), which is 180°C lower compared to the bare CeO2. The presence of gold strongly boosted conversion both to acetone (maximum of 88% at 130°C compared to 35% at 335°C on CeO2) and to CO2 (90% conversion at 203°C compared to 380°C on CeO2). In the case of TiO2, Au had only a moderate effect on the catalytic performance (conversion curves shifted only ca. 10°C) than on the bare TiO2. An intermediate behaviour was found in the TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxide, where the presence of gold improved the catalytic performance mainly in the partial oxidation to acetone, whose conversion curve was anticipated of 80°C, whereas the total oxidation to CO2 was affected at a lower extent (light off about 10°C lower). 4 Discussion The results reported in the previous section clearly pointed out that the presence of CeO2 affects in a different way the catalytic and the photocatalytic performance of TiO2. In particular the catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol was strongly improved by coupling TiO2 with CeO2, already at low CeO2 amount, also with an effect on the selectivity towards oxidation products (Fig. 7), the partial oxidation to acetone being favoured by higher amounts of CeO2. The oxidation activity was strongly boosted by the presence of gold, which caused a significant decrease in the light-off temperatures of 2-propanol (Fig. 8). On the contrary in the photocatalytic oxidation (Fig. 9 ) the effect of CeO2 addition is negative in terms of 2-propanol conversion, whereas a sensible increase in the selectivity to CO2 was observed. Interestingly in this case a direct correlation between catalysts performance and percentage of CeO2 was found. It must be underlined that in the photocatalytic oxidation Au acts essentially favouring the total oxidation of the alcohol, increasing the selectivity towards CO2. The above behaviour indicates that, over the TiO2–CeO2 systems, catalytic and photocatalytic oxidation of 2-propanol takes place with two different reaction mechanisms. As far as the catalytic oxidation is concerned, activity and characterization data here reported confirm that over reducible oxides based systems, such as CeO2 or TiO2–CeO2, reaction mechanism involves CeO2 lattice oxygens through a Mars–Van-Krevelen pathway. A higher mobility of these oxygens has been reported to be beneficial for oxidation reactions [14,16,77]. When gold is also present it can been suggested that CeO2 lattice oxygens and chemisorbed oxygen at the gold-oxide interface (Au–TiO2–CeO2 or Au–CeO2) are involved with a comparable effect in the deep oxidation of VOC’s to CO2 [6,81–83]. TPR profiles (Fig. 5) confirmed a much higher mobility of surface CeO2 oxygens over Au/CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2, due to the interaction of gold with the support, thus explaining the much higher activity of these systems in the catalytic oxidation of the alcohol. Furthermore DRIFT data pointed out a decrease of surface CeO2 oxygen basicity by gold addition to CeO2 while a minor effect was noted in the presence of TiO2 (an acid oxide) in TiO2–CeO2 sample. A high basicity degree can be correlated to an increase of oxygen mobility, beneficial for the oxidation reactions [84]. These effects showed the key role of the mutual Au–CeO2 interaction in the 2-propanol catalytic oxidation. The strong interaction between gold and CeO2 was also highlighted by XRD, Raman and EDX data, showing a higher crystallinity and a CeO2 surface enrichment in the Au/TiO2–CeO2 system compared to bare TiO2–CeO2. In the photocatalytic oxidation the role of CeO2 in TiO2 is controversial. Di Paola et al. found that the activity of TiO2 in the photo-degradation of 4-Nitrophenol was reduced by the presence of transition metal ions, probably because a higher amount of the dopant covered the TiO2 surface active sites [85]. On the other hand in a recent paper Meksi et al., found that the incorporation of cerium at the surface of TiO2, due to its larger ionic radius, generates lattice distortion and creation of surface oxygen vacancies, which restrain the crystallite growth of anatase. XRD patterns reported in the present paper confirmed that mixed TiO2–CeO2 catalysts exhibited TiO2 anatase crystallites smaller than those found on bare TiO2. The paper of Meksi et al. also evidenced that the formation of Ce3+ impurities on the CeO2 particles probably results from the injection of electrons from TiO2 to the Ce 4f level. This would also contribute to the enhancement of photoproduced hole life-times [86]. A similar positive effect due to the incorporation of Ce in the TiO2 was also found by Belver et al. [87]. Moreover Yan et al., found a direct correlation for both anatase and rutile between the surface specific photocatalytic activity and the surface/bulk defect density ratio, which influences the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs on TiO2 [88]. The increase of CO2 selectivity with the amount of CeO2 found in this work could be explained by considering the surface active species involved in the reaction. When the photogenerated holes and electrons move to the surface of TiO2, the electrons reduce the electron acceptor (O2) to active oxygen (O2 −) and the holes oxidize donors, namely adsorbed H2O or hydroxyl groups [89] which produce hydroxyl radicals OH·. The active oxygen O2 − and the hydroxyl radicals OH· are able to oxidize the adsorbed organic molecules (VOC’s) being more active than the gas phase O2 of the conventional thermocatalysis on CeO2, in so as they can migrate to the CeO2 surface, favouring the re-oxidation of ceria thus accelerating its redox process [90]. Therefore, similarly to the catalytic oxidation mechanism, the higher reducibility/mobility of CeO2 and the presence of more active species (active oxygen and hydroxyl radicals) were beneficial for the total oxidation reaction. Moreover the basic and the redox nature of CeO2 sites respect to the more acid sites of TiO2 could favour the direct oxidation of 2-propanol to CO2 [77,80,91]. These effects were more evident when gold was also present. In fact, the strong interaction between gold and CeO2 favours the mobility of surface CeO2 oxygens leading also to a surface enrichment of cerium that could favour the migration of active sites (O2 −, OH·) at gold-CeO2 interface. From a practical point of view it is possible to point out that the choice of catalytic or photocatalytic oxidation over oxide supported gold systems provides a versatile approach to direct the process towards the desired reaction products. In fact, the use of the catalytic process with gold supported on CeO2 resulted in the best performance in the total oxidation of 2-propanol to CO2, whereas gold supported on mixed TiO2–CeO2 oxides exhibited the highest selectivity to partial oxidation to acetone. In the photocatalytic process the bare TiO2 and Au/TiO2 catalysts are the best systems to convert 2-propanol to acetone at room temperature whereas Au/TiO2–CeO2 gave the highest selectivity to CO2. 5 Conclusions Gold supported catalysts showed a high versatility, as Au/CeO2 was the best catalyst for the oxidation of 2-propanol to CO2, Au/TiO2 the best one for the photocatalytic conversion of the alcohol to acetone and Au/TiO2–CeO2 exhibited a high selectivity to acetone in the catalytic oxidation and a high CO2 selectivity in the photocatalytic oxidation of 2-propanol. On the basis of characterization data (XRD, Raman spectroscopy, EDX, BET Surface area determinations, H2-TPR, DRIFT and DRS) it was proposed that interaction of gold with TiO2 causes an enhancement in the oxidation activity in the photocatalytic experiments, due to an increase of the charge separation between the excited electron and the hole of TiO2, whereas the coexistence of gold and both TiO2 and CeO2 oxides favours the total oxidation of the alcohol to CO2. The catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol is instead mainly directed by the presence of a reducible oxide support as CeO2, necessary to enable a strong interaction with gold nanoparticles, providing very active lattice oxygens. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic and catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol, representative of volatile organic compounds (VOC’s), were compared over mixed TiO2–CeO2-based catalysts. The effect of different amounts of CeO2 and the presence of gold (1wt%) on TiO2 was investigated. In the photocatalytic oxidation CeO2 had a negative effect on the performance towards the alcohol conversion of both TiO2–CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts, being Au/TiO2 the most active system. On the contrary mixed TiO2–CeO2 and Au/TiO2–CeO2 samples showed a higher catalytic oxidation efficiency for 2-propanol conversion compared to the single oxides. In this case Au/CeO2 catalyst had the best performance. On the basis of characterization data (XRD, Raman spectroscopy, EDX, BET Surface area determinations, H2-TPR, DRIFT and DRS), it was proposed that the interaction of gold with TiO2 caused an enhancement of the partial photo-oxidation activity to acetone due to an increase of the charge separation between the excited electron and the hole of TiO2, whereas the coexistence of gold and both TiO2 and CeO2 oxides favoured the total oxidation of the alcohol to CO2. The catalytic oxidation of 2-propanol is, instead, mainly directed by the presence of a reducible oxide support as CeO2, necessary to enable a strong interaction with gold nanoparticles, providing very active lattice oxygen atoms.
coredata.dc:title: A comparison between photocatalytic and catalytic oxidation of 2-Propanol over Au/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts
